channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hong Kong Holds Vote as Officials Move Against ‘Anti-China’ Elements
item.description: The government is pushing hard to raise turnout in an election overshadowed by a deadly fire and public anger over safety lapses and official accountability.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: The burned Wang Fuk Court apartment complex in Hong Kong last month.

item.title: In Brazil’s Answer to Hollywood, Dreams and Drought Share the Stage
item.description: A dusty town in the parched northeast has become the nation’s show business destination. But climate change and technology are posing new challenges there.
item.dc:creator: Ana Ionova and Dado Galdieri
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times

item.title: Leak Highlights Poor State of Louvre Infrastructure
item.description: Up to 400 documents have been damaged by the leak, according to Francis Steinbock, the deputy administrator of the museum. But no works of art were affected.
item.dc:creator: Ségolène Le Stradic
item.media:description: Francis Steinbock, the deputy administrator of the Louvre, said that documents had been damaged in a leak from a water pipe in the library of the Egyptian antiquities department.

item.title: Russian Drone Strike on Chernobyl Hasn’t Led to Rise in Radiation Levels
item.description: Despite the finding, the authorities have been unable to fix the damage from a drone that punctured Reactor No. 4’s outermost protective shield in February.
item.dc:creator: Kim Barker
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Emergency workers outside the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in February after the confinement structure was punctured by a Russian drone in Pripyat, Ukraine.

item.title: Benin Coup Attempt to Oust Talon Has Been Foiled, Interior Minister Says
item.description: A spokesman said 14 members of the military had been arrested. The West African country’s president, who was not seen for hours, appeared on television Sunday night and said the coup plot would “not go unpunished.”
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg, Saikou Jammeh and Ephrat Livni
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:description: Soldiers patrolled in front of Benin’s radio and television offices in Cotonou on Sunday after an apparent coup attempt.

item.title: Australia’s Social Media Ban for Under-16s Is Coming. The Teenagers Are Skeptical.
item.description: The country is trying to wean children under 16 off the likes of TikTok, Snapchat, YouTube and Instagram with a new law. The teenagers are skeptical.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim and Matthew Abbott
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times

item.title: How Australia’s Social Media Ban for Children Will Work
item.description: The country is barring children under 16 from social media, with a sweeping federal law that is one of the first attempts at a nationwide regulation.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: James Tomlinson, 9, playing a game on a phone in Melbourne, Australia.

item.title: Hong Kong Man Arrested After Posting Online About Deadly Fire
item.description: The arrest was part of a crackdown on speech that the authorities say is inciting hatred of the government. Critics say officials are silencing calls for accountability.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson
item.media:credit: Billy H.C. Kwok for The New York
item.media:description: Crowds watching the fire at the Wang Fuk Court apartment complex on Nov. 27 in Hong Kong.

item.title: Fire at a Nightclub in Goa, India, Kills at Least 25
item.description: Officials said they were investigating the blaze in the southwestern state of Goa, a popular tourist destination.
item.dc:creator: Pragati K.B. and Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: The burned remains of the Birch by Romeo Lane nightclub in Goa, India, on Sunday.

item.title: Battlefield Picture Worsening for Ukraine as Trump Pushes Peace Plan
item.description: Russian forces have advanced on several fronts recently. President Vladimir V. Putin signaled after talks with U.S. officials that he was not budging from demands.
item.dc:creator: Cassandra Vinograd, Oleksandr Chubko and Maria Varenikova
item.media:description: The 148th Artillery Brigade of the Ukrainian Army in October in the Zaporizhzhia region of eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Trump’s Security Doctrine Leaves Europe at a Strategic Crossroads
item.description: A new White House policy document formalizes President Trump’s long-held contempt for Europe’s leaders. It made clear that the continent now stands at a strategic crossroads.
item.dc:creator: Jason Horowitz
item.media:credit: Davide Monteleone for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Norwegian soldier during a NATO military exercise this year. European governments have tried to wean themselves off American military might by increasing their own military spending and cooperation.

item.title: Venezuela’s Nobel Winner Will Go to Norway for Peace Prize, Official Says
item.description: Venezuelan officials say María Corina Machado will be considered a fugitive if she goes to Oslo, laying bare the risks for the opposition leader.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero and Henrik Pryser Libell
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: María Corina Machado has united an often fractious opposition in recent years, but the Venezuelan authorities blocked her from running for president.

item.title: At Least 17 Migrants Die in Greece’s Worst Shipwreck in Two Years
item.description: Two people were rescued from a half-sunken boat off the island of Crete on Saturday evening, but 17 others died in the wreck.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
item.media:description: Firefighters and members of the Hellenic coast responding after a migrant vessel sank off the island of Crete, on Saturday.

item.title: Israel Backed Gazans to Oppose Hamas. For One, It Ended Violently.
item.description: Officials said Israel helped arm and back Yasser Abu Shabab’s Popular Forces, part of a strategy against Hamas, before a local clan killed him this week.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: A destroyed area of Rafah, Gaza. Yasser Abu Shabab and his militia group were based near the city.

item.title: Thailand Launches Airstrikes on Cambodia in New Wave of Violence
item.description: Each side accused the other of firing first. The fighting came weeks after President Trump had cast himself as a peacemaker in the decades-old border dispute.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Muktita Suhartono
item.media:description: The fighting ignited panic among civilians in both countries. Some people in Cambodia’s Preah Vihear province moved away from the border on Monday.

item.title: Firefighter Is Killed as Multiple Wildfires Burn in Australia
item.description: The firefighter died after being struck by a tree. Dozens of homes in two states have been lost as hot, windy conditions point to a challenging fire season.
item.dc:creator: Victoria Kim
item.media:credit: Dan Himbrechts/Australian Associated Press, via Reuters
item.media:description: Firefighters at work in Koolewong in the Australian state of New South Wales on Saturday.

item.title: 8 Matisse Works Stolen From Library in Brazil
item.description: Two armed men stole over a dozen pieces of art from a São Paulo exhibition featuring works by the French painter and other artists.
item.dc:creator: Jin Yu Young
item.media:description: A police car in front of the Mario de Andrade Library in São Paulo, Brazil, on Sunday.

item.title: United Nations Cuts Its 2026 Emergency Aid Budget in Half
item.description: Huge reductions in foreign aid by the United States and Europe have led the U.N.’s emergency relief coordinator to slash its fund-raising targets for next year.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: Tom Fletcher, the United Nations under secretary general for humanitarian affairs, said U.N. agencies have been “under attack” as the United States and Europe have reduced the amount of international aid they give.

item.title: Dogs in Kimonos: Japan Reinvents a Children’s Holiday With Pets in Mind
item.description: A traditional Japanese festival is being adapted for poodles and Pomeranians, amid a booming pet industry and a dearth of children.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández, Hisako Ueno and Kentaro Takahashi
item.media:credit: Kentaro Takahashi for The New York Times

item.title: He Was a Russian Activist in Exile. His Own Wife Accused Him of Spying.
item.description: Poland has charged a little-known Russian opposition figure with espionage and participating in a bomb plot. His friends are perplexed.
item.dc:creator: Nataliya Vasilyeva
item.media:description: Igor Rogov in the Polish Parliament building.

item.title: U.S. Deports Second Planeload of Iranians, Officials Say
item.description: The plane, carrying about 50 Iranians and other deportees, took off from Arizona on Sunday, under a deal the Trump administration reached with Iran two months ago.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Tehran on Sunday. The identities of the Iranians being deported from the United States, and their individual circumstances, were not immediately clear.

item.title: The New Syria
item.description: The country certainly still faces many challenges. But some things are now going right there — and those are worth our attention, too.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:description: Celebrating one year after the fall of Bashar al-Assad in Hama, Syria, on Friday.

item.title: Katy Perry Posts Photos With Justin Trudeau Amid Romance Rumors
item.description: Ms. Perry and Mr. Trudeau, the former prime minister of Canada, posed together in photos and videos on Instagram, making them “Instagram official.”
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Jordan Strauss/Invision, via Associated Press, Miguel a Lopes, via EPA, via Shutterstock

item.title: Martin Parr, Who Photographed Britain’s Unvarnished Quirks, Dies at 73
item.description: Mr. Parr trademarked a hyperrealism in his photography that illuminated the “craziness of the English,” making small details loom larger than life.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Dolly Faibyshev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Martin Parr at a gala at the American Museum of Natural History in New York in 2023.

item.title: Heathrow Airport Is Briefly Locked Down After Spray Is Used in Altercation
item.description: One man was arrested after a substance that appeared to be pepper spray was used during a fight in one of the airport’s parking garages, the police said.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:description: Travelers at Heathrow Airport in Britain in September.

item.title: With MaXhosa Africa, Laduma Ngxokolo Is Reweaving South Africa’s Story
item.description: Laduma Ngxokolo, the designer behind MaXhosa Africa, is on a mission to embrace his country’s history and traditions, rather than hide from them.
item.dc:creator: Yola Mzizi
item.media:description: Laduma Ngxokolo founded MaXhosa Africa in 2010, basing the label’s offerings on traditional Xhosa patterns and motifs, but reimagined for the modern world.

item.title: Japan Says China Aimed Military Radar at Its Fighter Jets
item.description: Beijing disputed the accusation, the latest flare-up in a festering dispute between the two countries.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Defense Ministry of Japan, via Reuters
item.media:description: The Liaoning, China’s first aircraft carrier, sailing near Okinawa, Japan, in 2021, in a photo released by Japan’s Defense Ministry.

item.title: In Honduras, Some Voters Were Swayed by Trump, Others Angered
item.description: President Trump backed Nasry Asfura days before the Nov. 30 election and denounced his opponents. In a close race, that has potentially tipped the scales.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner and Jeff Ernst
item.media:credit: Federico Rios for The New York Times
item.media:description: Downtown Tegucigalpa, the Honduran capital, on Saturday.

item.title: 12 People Killed in Mass Shooting at Illegal Tavern in South Africa
item.description: The police said they were searching for three assailants who opened fire, shooting 25 people. A 3-year-old boy was among the dead, while 13 survivors were being treated in the hospital.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: The scene of a mass shooting in Pretoria, South Africa, on Saturday.

item.title: China’s National Security Office in Hong Kong Summons Foreign Journalists
item.description: The authorities accused “some foreign media” of smearing the government’s response to a fire at a high-rise complex, saying: “Do not say you have not been warned.”
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Smoke rising from the Wang Fuk Court residential complex in Hong Kong last month. Beijing’s national security arm in Hong Kong said that some foreign news outlets had twisted facts and spread false information.

item.title: Sweet Season
item.description: Rejoice: NYT Cooking’s holiday cookie extravaganza has returned.
item.dc:creator: Emily Weinstein
item.media:credit: Rachel Vanni for The New York Times. Food Stylist: Samantha Seneviratne. Prop Stylist: Megan Hedgpeth.

item.title: Like Trump, Benjamin Franklin Sought to Annex Canada
item.description: A book revives the largely forgotten story of how one of America’s most famous founding fathers tried to make Canada a part of his new nation.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.category: He Did Not Conquer: Benjamin Franklin's Failure to Annex Canada (Book)
item.media:credit: Mark Makela for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sculpture of Benjamin Franklin in Philadelphia.

item.title: Afrikaner Access Soars Amid Trump’s Policy Shift
item.description: The white descendants of Europeans who colonized the country are getting greater access to American officials this year, both in Washington and in Pretoria.
item.dc:creator: John Eligon
item.media:description: White South Africans rallied in support of President Trump in February outside the U.S. Embassy in Pretoria, South Africa.

item.title: Saudi Arabia Will Sell You Alcohol Now, if You’re Rich Enough
item.description: The conservative Islamic kingdom’s approach to social policy change is often silence and ambiguity. Legalizing alcohol has been no different.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Nonalcoholic draft beer served at a cafe this year in Riyadh, Saudi Arabia. The kingdom has banned alcohol for more than 70 years.

item.title: Scientists Are Measuring Ocean Currents in Hopes of Charting AMOC’s Future
item.description: Scientists fear warming is driving a collapse in the ocean currents that shape climate far and wide. The ice-choked waters off Greenland might hold the key.
item.dc:creator: Raymond Zhong and Esther Horvath
item.media:description: Scoresby Sound, a fjord in eastern Greenland, as seen from the research ship.

item.title: Survivors of the Deadly Hong Kong Fire Are in Limbo
item.description: Hong Kong, with some of the world’s highest housing costs and inequality, must now figure out how to help thousands of residents who lost friends, family and homes.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, Theodora Yu and Joy Dong
item.media:description: Wang Fuk Court, a residential estate in the Tai Po district of Hong Kong, after a blaze damaged the complex late last month.

item.title: China’s Mad at Japan, and Pop Stars Are Paying for It
item.description: Beijing is curbing Japanese movies, music and art as it seeks to punish Tokyo for its support of Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Hisako Ueno

item.title: Trump’s Security Strategy Focuses on Profit, Not Spreading Democracy
item.description: President Trump’s new National Security Strategy describes a country that is focused on doing business and reducing migration while avoiding passing judgment on authoritarians.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump at the White House last month. The National Security Strategy his administration released describes a world in which American interests are far narrower than how prior administrations — even in his first term — had portrayed them.

item.title: Man Who Swallowed Stolen Fabergé Egg Passes It Naturally, Police Say
item.description: The man ingested the egg locket at a jewelry store in New Zealand last week, according to the authorities.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:credit: New Zealand Police, via Associated Press
item.media:description: “No medical intervention was required, and the pendant passed naturally,” the police said in a statement.

item.title: ICE Arrests Harvard Professor Charged for Shooting a Pellet Gun
item.description: Carlos Portugal Gouvea, a visiting law professor from Brazil, said he would leave the U.S. rather than be deported, according to federal officials. He was arrested after firing a pellet gun near a synagogue.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: Billy Hickey for The New York Times
item.media:description: The professor, who is from Brazil, had been teaching at Harvard during the fall semester.

item.title: Trump Wants Maduro to Go. Here’s Who Could Replace Him in Venezuela.
item.description: Several senior Venezuelan officials and opposition politicians would have a claim to power in a transition, but all would face difficulties.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela holding a sword during a speech last month. Should he end up losing power, his potential replacement would be largely determined by the manner of his departure.

item.title: Wary of Russia, German Defense Minister Pistorius Is Growing His Army
item.description: Boris Pistorius, Germany’s defense minister, is pushing to expand its military in case tensions with Russia escalate. That’s tricky in a country where the Nazi era casts a long shadow.
item.dc:creator: Christopher F. Schuetze
item.media:description: Boris Pistorius, Germany’s defense minister, speaking to lawmakers in Berlin on Friday.

item.title: U.S. Warns of Europe’s ‘Civilizational Erasure’ Through Immigration
item.description: America’s goal should be “to help Europe correct its current trajectory,” the administration said in its new National Security Strategy.
item.dc:creator: Michael D. Shear, Jeanna Smialek and Lara Jakes
item.media:description: President Trump has made no secret of his disdain for the political leadership in Europe.

item.title: Putin Basks in Praise From Modi on India Visit
item.description: Prime Minister Narendra Modi lauded President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, underlining the close personal relationship between the leaders and their countries’ longtime friendship.
item.dc:creator: Anupreeta Das and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Prime Minister Narendra Modi of India in New Delhi on Friday. They pledged deeper cooperation in defense, trade and energy.

item.title: Air Traffic Control Issue Briefly Grounds Flights at Edinburgh Airport
item.description: The airport, Scotland’s busiest, said it had experienced a technical problem with its air traffic control provider. An hour later, flights had resumed.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: Edinburgh Airport in Scotland in 2012.

item.title: How the U.S. Focus on Fentanyl Helped Fuel the Cocaine Trade’s Resurgence
item.description: Across Latin America, cocaine trafficking has surged as Washington has prioritized combating fentanyl. Times reporters traveled to Ecuador to see how criminal groups are wreaking havoc.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The police in Spain displaying tons of cocaine last year at the port in Algeciras after it was transported in a container from Ecuador.

item.title: The ‘Cocaine Superhighway’ Fueled by the U.S. Focus on Fentanyl
item.description: As Washington made combating fentanyl a priority, cocaine trafficking has surged. Nowhere have the ripples been felt like in Ecuador, where criminal groups have run rampant.
item.dc:creator: Maria Abi-Habib, José María León Cabrera and Daniele Volpe
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: The aftermath of a car bombing in Guayaquil, Ecuador. Car bombs have become common, killing and terrorizing civilians, and gangs frequently clash with the military and the police.

item.title: How Batteries Got Cheaper and Made the Electric Grid More Reliable
item.description: An early grid battery was installed in the Atacama Desert in Chile 15 years ago. Now, as prices have tumbled, they are increasingly being used around the world.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Ruth Fremson
item.media:description: Employees working on battery units at the solar project, which is owned by AES, a Virginia company that holds utilities and power plants across the world.

item.title: Zelensky’s Government Sabotaged Oversight, Allowing Corruption in Ukraine to Fester
item.description: Ukrainian leaders blame independent advisers for failing to prevent graft. A Times investigation found that President Volodymyr Zelensky’s own administration removed guardrails.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut and Kim Barker
item.category: European Bank for Reconstruction and Development
item.media:description: President Volodymyr Zelensky, center right, at the nuclear power plant in the Khmelnytskyi region of western Ukraine in February.

item.title: Gianni Infantino Awards Trump a FIFA Peace Prize and Announces World Cup Draw
item.description: Gianni Infantino, head of soccer’s governing body, has been ingratiating himself with the president to help ensure a successful 2026 World Cup.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Luke Broadwater
item.category: Kennedy, John F, Center for the Performing Arts
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump, holding a replica of the men’s World Cup, with Gianni Infantino, the president of FIFA, in the Oval Office in August. Mr. Trump later asked to keep the trophy.

item.title: Trump’s Relationship With the President of FIFA
item.description: Gianni Infantino, head of soccer’s governing body, FIFA, has lauded President Trump at almost every opportunity, even starting a FIFA Peace Prize after Mr. Trump didn’t win the Nobel. Luke Broadwater, a White House reporter, describes the bromance.
item.dc:creator: Luke Broadwater, Karen Hanley and James Surdam

item.title: On Pope Leo’s Visit to Lebanon and Turkey, A.I. Was a Frequent Concern
item.description: On his first trip as pontiff, Leo XIV predictably called for peace and unity. But he also addressed technology’s promise and pitfalls.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Leo in Bkerke, Lebanon, on Monday. During his six-day tour, he called out the risks of artificial intelligence and other rapidly advancing technologies.

item.title: Yemen’s Civil War Could Escalate Again. Here’s What to Know.
item.description: An armed group backed by the United Arab Emirates has pushed into the oil-rich province of Hadramout, a move that could reignite conflict in Yemen after years of a stalemate.
item.dc:creator: Ismaeel Naar and Vivian Nereim
item.media:description: Forces loyal to the Southern Transitional Council during clashes with pro-government forces in Abyan Province, Yemen, in 2020.

item.title: Trump Trumpets Peace in Africa Amid War on Drug Boats, in Day of Dissonance
item.description: President Trump presided over a Congo-Rwanda peace deal on the same day his administration was being questioned about potential war crimes.
item.dc:creator: Shawn McCreesh
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:description: President Trump trumpeted a peace agreement while hosting President Paul Kagame of Rwanda and President Felix Tshisekedi of the Democratic Republic of Congo in Washington on Thursday.

item.title: Stellantis Is in Default for Moving Jeep Production to U.S., Canada Says
item.description: The automaker switched production from Ontario in a bid to please President Trump. But the company defaulted on contracts covering hundreds of millions of dollars in assistance, Canada said.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: Stellantis’s plant in Brampton, Canada. The European-based automaker also produces vehicles under the Chrysler, Dodge and Ram brands in North America.

item.title: When Kids Adopt New Technologies, Hype Can Turn to Backlash
item.description: The arc of mobile phones and social media may foretell the future of artificial intelligence in schools.
item.dc:creator: Katrin Bennhold
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times

item.title: Dominik Duka, Czech Cardinal Jailed Under Communism, Dies at 82
item.description: While in prison in 1981, he befriended the dissident and future Czech president Vaclav Havel. Later, he became a conservative voice in Rome.
item.dc:creator: Clay Risen
item.media:description: Dominik Duka in 2010, when he became the archbishop of Prague. Cardinal Duka spent much of his early life under one of the most anti-religious governments in Communist Europe.

item.title: U.N. Warns of ‘Another Wave of Atrocities’ in Sudan’s Civil War
item.description: Paramilitary groups have intensified an offensive on a crucial region bordering Darfur, prompting fears of another massacre.
item.dc:creator: Pranav Baskar
item.media:description: Displaced people from El Fasher, in Darfur, lined up for aid at a camp in northern Sudan last month.

item.title: After Years of Debate, Vatican Says No to Women Deacons, at Least for Now
item.description: But a papal commission examining the question said further study was required, and advised that women should be given other leadership roles in the Catholic Church.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pope Leo XIV in Beirut in November. Some campaigners had hoped that the Vatican, under Leo’s leadership, might allow for the inclusion of women in the lowest rungs of the church ministerial hierarchy.
